Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = x(t) + iy(t)\\) where \\(x(t)\\) and \\(y(t)\\) are real functions describing a signal. The signal undergoes a Fourier Transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) resulting in the transformed function \\(Z(\\omega)\\).

If a damping function \\(e^{-at}\\), where \\(a\\) is a positive constant, is applied to \\(z(t)\\) before the Fourier Transform, will the modified transform \\(Z'(\\omega)\\) depend only on the original \\(Z(\\omega)\\), not on the parameter \\(a\\)?
Explanation: The application of the damping function directly affects the time domain signal, leading to a convolution in the frequency domain with the transform of \\(e^{-at}\\). This results in a transform that depends on both \\(Z(\\omega)\\) and the damping parameter \\(a\\), reflecting the effect of the intervention.
